Lab Members


Jian Li (李健)
Principal Investigator
li.jian (at) pku.edu.cn
Scholar Citations

My research interests evolve around the questions regarding human affective learning (reward and punishment) and decision-making. More specifically, I am interested in how human extract salient information to guide their behavior in an uncertain environment. I also focus on bridging the gap between learning-driven decision-making and those economic decision-making processes that do not have obvious learning components. One line of research projects concerns the understanding of how the circuitry of value related brain areas orchestrates to make consistent choices in inter-temporal decision making tasks. A second set of research seeks to understand how first and second order (variance and volatility) would impact people’s social behavior. A third line of research centers on better understanding the interaction of basal ganglia and prefrontal cortex in generating preferences and choices.


Weiwei Li (李维维)
Graduate Student

Weiwei Li is a PhD student in Jian’s lab. She is generally interested in cognitive and neural mechanisms of economic decision-making. Recently, using fMRI and behavior modeling, she is working on projects investigating the potential factors impacting human risk decision-making behavior, including personality, temporal delay, and sensitivity to probabilities.


Jingwei Sun (孙经纬)
Graduate Student
sun.jingwei (at) pku.edu.cn

Jingwei is a PhD student, working on how humans learn to make decisions with uncertainty, with a focus on reinforcement learning modeling. In particular, she is interested in how positive and negative information would affect humans’s choices and why. She has a bachelor’s degree in Psychology from Peking University.


Jiashu Wang (王嘉澍)
Graduate Student
wangjiashu1991 (at) 163.com

Jiashu Wang was born in 1991 in Xi’an, Shaanxi Province. He got his bachelor degree in Psychology from Peking University in 2015. Now he is a PhD student in Jian’s Lab. Jiashu is interested in the psychological and neural mechanisms underlying people’s decisions, especially how human process and integrate information when they make economic choices. He has rich experience using fMRI, tDCS, modelling and behavioral methods to explore the topics including temporal discount, reward and memory, social conformity and sunk cost. Recently, his work focuses on mental accounting — the set of cognitive processes to “organize, evaluate, and keep track of financial activities”.

Siru Chen (陈思如)
Undergraduate Research Assistant
csr (at) pku.edu.cn

Siru Chen is a junior of Yuanpei college majoring in Psychology at Peking University. She is interested in risk attitude in decision-making. Recently, she is working on a project investigating the influence of oxytocin on people’s decisions. During holidays, She likes travelling following her heart without fixed schedule. And she is also a movie enthusiast.


Haoxue Fan (樊浩雪)
Undergraduate Research Assistant
haoxuefan1997 (at) gmail.com

Haoxue Fan is a senior majoring in Psychology and minoring in Economics at Peking University. She is generally interested in social decision-making, especially how people deal with uncertainty when they interact with others and when they take other people’s opinions into consideration. She is also curious about the role of emotion in guiding people’s behavior. When she is not doing science, she is an enthusiastic traveller and foodie.
